instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video bad corrosion
threads.message: Board had pretty bad rust and corrosion. At first I was getting video on the built in display, but I stuck the board in my ultrasonic cleaner and now I have no video. I am assuming the ultrasonic cleaner did more harm then good. I am getting no video on the built in display, and no video on an external monitor, however the external monitor does detect a signal. <CHIP>U5450</CHIP> is heavily damaged. I tried scraping in one area/pin of where one of the pads should be (<CHIP>U5450</CHIP>), but I got to ground. Any hope?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video bad corrosion
threads.message:
You can try without <TRANSISTOR>Q5450</TRANSISTOR>.
But need to trick T2, which supervises LCD backlight current.
Should solder a resistor between pads 6 & 10.
3-6K will simulate a current consumption of 1-2A aprox; test which value works better.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video bad corrosion
threads.message: No go, I did a bit more troubleshooting and I have no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>. Looks like this leads back to the processor. No luck?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video bad corrosion
threads.message:
Possibly knocked off component, or broken trace.
This can happens when ultrasonic hard corroded boards; especially if no sweep function used.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video bad corrosion
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 98521, member: 682"]
You can try without <TRANSISTOR>Q5450</TRANSISTOR>.
But need to trick T2, which supervises LCD backlight current.
Should solder a resistor between pads 6 & 10.
3-6K will simulate a current consumption of 1-2A aprox; test which value works better.
[/QUOTE]
Looks like this got it. I ended up using a 5.6k resistor, thank you! Now I just found it is locked down with an Apple ID.  ¡Ay, caramba!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video bad corrosion
threads.message: Seems that you've seen was <CHIP>U5450</CHIP>, not <TRANSISTOR>Q5450</TRANSISTOR>; sorry for error...
